places.name: Anglesey
places.description: Anglesey is an island, and county, on the north-west coast of Wales.

places.name: Mount Etna
places.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

places.name: Mount Vesuvius
places.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

places.name: Parys Mine
places.description: A mountain in Northern Wales known for copper-mining.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

places.name: Lake Solfatara
places.description: The lake is in the Campagna of Rome, Italy, near Tivoli.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: John JoachimBecher
persons.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

persons.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
persons.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Charles Francois de Cisternay duFay
persons.description: French chemist and superintedent of the Jardin du Roi, who worked on electricity. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AmbroseGodfrey-Hanckwitz
persons.description: German-born British apothecary who worked as Boyle's assistant and later became a phosphorus manufacturer. FRSL.

persons.name: Johan GottliebGahn
persons.description: Swedish chemist and metallurgist who isolated manganese in 1774.

persons.name: JeanHellot
persons.description: French chemist and journalist who contributed to early studies on phosphorus and worked on applied aspects in dyeing, metallurgy, mining, and porcelain manufacture. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Johann vonLöwenstern-Kunckel
persons.description: German/Swedish chemist and apothecary. Later director of the laboratory and glass works of Brandenburg.

persons.name: Étienne FrançoisGeoffroy
persons.description: French physician and chemist, best known for his 1718 affinity tables. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
persons.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
persons.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

persons.name: HennigBrand
persons.description: German alchemist who accidentally discovered phosphorus.

places.name: Hamburg
places.description: Hamburg is one of Germany's three city-states alongside Berlin and Bremen, and is surrounded by Schleswig-Holstein to the north and Lower Saxony to the south.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Mull
places.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.
